examples.en: I gave a round frisbee to a puppy as a present.
examples.ja: 円いフリスビーを子犬にプレゼントした。

examples.en: Is that circular thing over there a UFO?
examples.ja: あそこの円いのはUFOかな？

examples.en: The full moon is circular.
examples.ja: フルムーンの月は、円いです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji with hiragana attached to it. That hiragana ends with い which means it's an adjective. So, what's the adjective form of the kanji that's in this word? 円 means both "yen" and "round" but in this case we're looking at the round one (because something isn't going to be "yenny"). The adjective version of round is <vocabulary>round</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>circular</vocabulary>. Just like a yen coin, this "round" is a flat round. As in, if you draw a circle on a piece of paper, you could use this word. Same goes with yen, which is why "yen" and "round" both use the same kanji.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The reading for the 円 portion of this word is the same as a kanji you learned on level 2: 丸. That kanji means something really similar to this kanji. And guess what? They also share a reading. So, if you know that the reading of 丸 is まる then you'll also know that the reading for this word is <reading>まる</reading>!

examples.en: I tell the brothers apart by their eye colors.
examples.ja: 兄弟を目の色で見分ける。

examples.en: It's impossible to tell whether what the man said is true.
examples.ja: あの男が言ったことが本当かどうか見分けるなんてムリだよ。

examples.en: Are you able to distinguish between diamonds and stones?
examples.ja: ダイヤモンドと石ころを見分けることは出来ますか？

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>see</kanji> something, then you "separate" (分ける) it. This is the same thing as <vocabulary>to distinguish</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tell apart</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to recognize</vocabulary>. This verb is transitive, so you're doing the action to something. You're distinguishing between things or people.
reading_mnemonic: You should know the reading of 見 already. The second part, 分ける is a word you should have learned in the previous level. Combine that knowledge together and you get the reading for this word.

examples.en: There's a big alligator in this pond.
examples.ja: この池の中には、大きなワニがいます。

examples.en: We lost all the gold fish in the pond because of the rain.
examples.ja: 雨のせいで、池の金魚を全て失った。

examples.en: There are some big, old rocks and a bamboo grove near the pond.
examples.ja: 池の近くには、大きくて古い石や竹林があります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: If you fall into a <vocabulary>pond</vocabulary>, what sound do you make? <reading>EEEEK</reading> (いけ)! Or maybe you're just afraid of ponds (I don't blame you, there are probably snakes or leeches or alligators in there) and you EEEEK when someone mentions them.

examples.en: When is the next time?
examples.ja: 次回は、いつですか？

examples.en: Many people are coming to the next meeting.
examples.ja: 次回のミーティングには、たくさんの人が来ますよ。

examples.en: There's no next time. We only live once.
examples.ja: 次回なんてないんだよ。人生は一回しかないんだから。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> you look at this kanji, you should know that it means <vocabulary>next time</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I just saw the news about the Middle East on TV.
examples.ja: さっきテレビで中東のニュースを見ました。

examples.en: Falafel is a type of croquette born in the Middle East.
examples.ja: ファラフェルは中東生まれのコロッケです。

examples.en: The culture of waterpipe tobacco in the Middle East is also popular in foreign countries.
examples.ja: 中東の水タバコの文化は、外国でも人気です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>east</kanji> is more simply known as the <vocabulary>middle east</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses two on'yomi readings. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 東 (とう) with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help:

If you're in Japan but craving a taste of the <vocabulary>Middle East</vocabulary>, you should go to <reading>とう</reading>きょう. とうきょう's a very international city, so it's full of great spots to enjoy food from the Middle East. Turkish cuisine, Lebanese cuisine, Persian cuisine — you name it, とうきょう's got it.

examples.en: The sun is rising and it is getting brighter around here.
examples.ja: 日が出て、辺りが明るくなってきました。

examples.en: Around my ankle is a little red.
examples.ja: 足首の辺りが、少し赤いです。

examples.en: There is still a lot of snow around.
examples.ja: 辺りには、まだ雪がたくさん有ります。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji for <kanji>area</kanji>. This makes it have the same meaning as the kanji: <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>vicinity</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you think about an <vocabulary>area</vocabulary> that you're in, it's the place you're <reading>at</reading> (あた).

examples.en: Many cars pass by.
examples.ja: たくさんの車が通る。

examples.en: When I go to the company, I pass through the bamboo forest.
examples.ja: 竹の林を通って、会社に行きます。

examples.en: I pass by the convenience store in 3-chome every day.
examples.ja: 三丁目のコンビニの前は、毎日通りますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pass through</kanji> so the verb vocab version means things like <vocabulary>to pass through</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to travel along</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to stop by</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

There's something in front of you that you have <vocabulary>to pass through</vocabulary> but you can't. It's a wall. In order to pass through it, you decide to kick it as hard as you can to knock it down. Unfortunately, it is way stronger than you, and your toe explodes on contact. You yell: "<reading>TOE! OH!</reading>" (とお) and then just scream a lot.

examples.en: Can I give that horse carrots and apples?
examples.ja: あの馬に、ニンジンやリンゴをあげてもいいですか？

examples.en: There are many white horses in the meadow.
examples.ja: 草地には、白い馬がたくさんいます。

examples.en: It's fun to see horses running at full power.
examples.ja: 馬が全力で走るのを見るのは楽しいです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Imagine someone riding a horse. Who is that person? It's <reading>Uma</reading> (うま) Thurman, the famous actress.

examples.en: Sports cars have high horsepower.
examples.ja: スポーツカーは、高い馬力を持っています。

examples.en: I bought an air conditioner that has some horsepower for the company.
examples.ja: 会社用に馬力があるエアコンを買った。

examples.en: How much power is actually in one horsepower?
examples.ja: 一馬力の力の大きさは一体どのくらいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: This word was probably made pretty recently. A <kanji>horse</kanji>'s <kanji>power</kanji>? That is <vocabulary>horsepower</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two common on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Cars with high <vocabulary>horsepower</vocabulary> are usually driven by <reading>Ricky</reading> (りき). Ricky is well-known for loving all cars with a lot of horsepower, so he's often seen driving around in fancy sports cars. Vroom vroom Ricky!

examples.en: The staff's thought is to continue supporting the president.
examples.ja: スタッフは、これからも社長を支える考えだ。

examples.en: My father went to work every day to support my mother and me.
examples.ja: 父は母や私を支えるために毎日仕事へ行った。

examples.en: This rock does not have the power to support a tree any bigger than this.
examples.ja: この石に、これ以上大きな木を支える力はありません。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>support</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You need <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary> someone. In order to support them, you grab two saws. One saw and another saw. It's a <reading>saw saw</reading> (ささ) combination good enough to do all the supporting you need - and maybe cut some supports too.

examples.en: I go to the branch in that town every day.
examples.ja: 私は毎日、その町の支店に通っています。

examples.en: My brother bought a used car at the branch.
examples.ja: 兄は、その支店で中古の車を買いました。

examples.en: My husband is the branch manager of the New York branch.
examples.ja: 私の主人は、ニューヨーク支店の支店長です。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>support</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is the <vocabulary>branch office</vocabulary>. Presumably this is because the regular "shop" is the "shop" and anything that supports it is the local (branch) office.

If it helps, this word has the same meaning as 支局 which you will also be learning in this level.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm planning to live in Tokyo next year.
examples.ja: 来年から、東京に住むつもりです。

examples.en: Can people who live abroad make a Japanese credit card?
examples.ja: 海外に住んでいる人でも、日本のクレジットカードは作れますか？

examples.en: When I was living in China, my youngest sister was born.
examples.ja: 中国に住んでいる時に、末の妹が生まれました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dwell</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to live</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to reside</vocabulary>, or of course <vocabulary>to dwell</vocabulary>. Basically, someone is living somewhere. Where do you live?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have a place to live... but not for long. You are being <reading>sue</reading>d (す) out of your house and home so you will have nowhere <vocabulary>to dwell</vocabulary>.

examples.en: There are a lot of residents in this apartment.
examples.ja: このアパートには、たくさんの住人がいます。

examples.en: Residents in town have a cherry blossom viewing party every April.
examples.ja: 町内の住人たちは、毎年四月に花見パーティーをします。

examples.en: Apparently, the resident of Room 202 is a famous manga artist.
examples.ja: ２０２号室の住人、有名なマンガ作家らしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>dwell</kanji> somewhere and you’re a <kanji>person</kanji>, that makes you a <vocabulary>resident</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

All the <vocabulary>resident</vocabulary>s in my area care about is <reading>jew</reading>els and <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (じゅうにん). Their houses are crammed full of jewels and Nintendo stuff. How about the residents of your town? I bet they all love jewels and Nintendo too.

examples.en: I went into the river to help the horse.
examples.ja: 私は、その馬を助けるために川に入りました。

examples.en: I am one yen short. Can you help me?
examples.ja: お金が一円足りないんです。助けてもらえませんか？

examples.en: Thanks to you saving me on that rainy day, I am who I am today.
examples.ja: あなたが、あの雨の日に助けてくれたおかげで、今の私がいます。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>help</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary>. Don't confuse this with 助かる which means "to be helped." You know that 助ける is "to help" because you're doing the helping. You know that you're doing the helping because you <reading>care</reading> (ける).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You need <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> someone. Someone is hanging off a cliff and out of reach. They ask you, the person standing above them, to <reading>toss</reading> (たす) them a rope, but you refuse. "TOSS IT!" they yell. "I WILL NOT TOSS IT," you respond. You're a jerk.

examples.en: This is advice from my dad.
examples.ja: これは、お父さんからの助言です。

examples.en: The president gave useful advice to all the staff.
examples.ja: 社長は全てのスタッフに役に立つ助言をしました。

examples.en: My mother advised me about being independent.
examples.ja: 母は私に自立するための助言をしてくれました。

examples.en: I will give you advice, if you give me that chocolate.
examples.ja: そのチョコレートをくれたら、助言をあげるわ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>help</kanji> with what you <kanji>say</kanji>, you're giving <vocabulary>advice</vocabulary>.

This word is commonly found in formal or professional contexts. In more casual settings, you can just use アドバイス (advise) instead.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It costs money to enter a medical university.
examples.ja: 医大に入るにはお金がかかります。

examples.en: My former partner was a teacher at a medical school.
examples.ja: 元パートナーは医大の先生でした。

examples.en: Not all students at med school become doctors.
examples.ja: 医大の学生がみんな医者になるわけではないですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 大学 to mean "college." So take the 大 and put it with <kanji>medicine</kanji> to create "medicine college", or <vocabulary>medical university</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your local <vocabulary>medical university</vocabulary> really prides itself on its <reading>ea</reading>gle <reading>dye</reading> (いだい). It's the only dye in the world made straight out of eagles. A bit strange for a medical university, but impressive nonetheless!

examples.en: I study medicine at university.
examples.ja: 大学では医学を学びます。

examples.en: Thanks to medical technology, my mother is still alive and healthy today.
examples.ja: 医学のテクノロジーのおかげで、私の母は今日も元気に生きています。

examples.en: From your perspective as a teacher who knows a lot about medicine, what do you think?
examples.ja: 医学にくわしい先生の見方としては、どう思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>study</kanji> of <kanji>medicine</kanji> is <vocabulary>medical science</vocabulary>. It can also be called <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>, but make sure to think of it as the "medicine" where it has to do with "medical science."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have to go see a doctor today.
examples.ja: 今日は医者に行かなくちゃいけない。

examples.en: As a physician my mission is to make people healthy.
examples.ja: 私の医者としてのミッションは人々を元気にすることです。

examples.en: I don't like seeing blood, but can I still be a doctor?
examples.ja: 私は血を見るのがきらいですが、医者にはなれますか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who works in <kanji>medicine</kanji> is a <vocabulary>doctor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This town was once a monarchy.
examples.ja: この町はかつて君主国だったそうです。

examples.en: A monarchy is a country where the leader is a king or queen.
examples.ja: 君主国は王や女王がリーダーの国のことです。

examples.en: Denmark is a monarchy.
examples.ja: デンマークは君主国です。

meaning_mnemonic: One <kanji>ruler</kanji> is the <kanji>master</kanji> of this entire <kanji>country</kanji>. Why, this sounds quite like a <vocabulary>monarchy</vocabulary> to me.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Are you perhaps Koichi's younger sister?
examples.ja: 君、もしかしてコウイチの妹？

examples.en: The curry you make is the best in Japan.
examples.ja: 君の作るカレーが日本一だよ。

examples.en: You taught me the importance of taking a shower every day, right?
examples.ja: 君は私に毎日シャワーをあびる大切さを教えてくれたじゃないか。

meaning_mnemonic: Okay, so the kanji itself means <kanji>buddy</kanji> and so does the word, but it also means <vocabulary>you</vocabulary> as well. This is one of the several ways to say "you" in Japanese, and this one is kind of an "affectionate" you. Maybe you'd say it with someone you're close to. Maybe you'd say it with a girlfriend or boyfriend. You wouldn't want to use it with your boss or teacher, though. Make sure to keep that in mind. It's kind of like saying "hey buddy" or "hey you," after all.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Who's your <vocabulary>buddy</vocabulary>? It's <reading>Kimmy</reading> (きみ)! If you know a Kimmy, imagine her. If you don't, find a famous Kimmy or make up a Kimmy to imagine. You ask... is it you?? Wait, you're my buddy?

examples.en: Michael has no brothers.
examples.ja: マイケル君には兄弟がいません。

examples.en: Tanaka-kun, you look well today.
examples.ja: 田中君、今日も元気そうだね。

examples.en: Yamashita-sensei calls both male and female students with "-kun."
examples.ja: 山下先生は、男女両方の学生に「〜君」を付けます。

meaning_mnemonic: Add this to the end of someone's name, it's like saying ______<kanji>buddy</kanji>. It's generally used as a name ender (like さん) for boys and young men. Don't use this on people who are higher ranked than you (socially or literally). As in, you wouldn't use it on your boss. Use it on your younger male subordinates as well as boys who aren't adults yet.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (on'yomi), probably because it usually is attached to other words (aka names, like こういち君) making it act more like jukugo words do.

examples.en: How much is the rate of the yen compared to the dollar now?
examples.ja: ドルに対する円のレートは、今いくらですか？

examples.en: Above is my perspective on diplomacy with the United States.
examples.ja: 以上が、米国との外交に対する見方です。

examples.en: Please tell me your thoughts on robot engineering.
examples.ja: 先生のロボット工学に対する考えを教えて下さい。

examples.en: It’s clear now that their relationship will never work because their opinions on Star Trek are the complete opposite.
examples.ja: あいつらの関係が修復不可能だってことは明らかだね。だって、スタートレックに対する意見が全く違っているんだから。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you do (する) <kanji>versus</kanji>, you choose <vocabulary>to face</vocabulary> an opponent. It’s where your attention and efforts are going to <vocabulary>be directed toward</vocabulary>. Alternatively, you can use this word <vocabulary>to contrast</vocabulary> one thing with another.

This word is used to help point out the relationship between two things in a sentence, where one thing is focusing on another thing. This is all a little vague and perhaps confusing, so check out the collocations and context sentences to get a better grasp of this word!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this word no problem.

examples.en: I'm opposed to the idea.
examples.ja: その考えには反対です。

examples.en: Um, your right and left sandals are on opposite feet.
examples.ja: あの、そのサンダル、右と左が反対ですよ。

examples.en: My father was opposed to me proposing in a Walmart.
examples.ja: 父は、私がウォルマートでプロポーズすることを反対した。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>versus</kanji>... You'd think this would be a double negative, but it's like a lot of other words where you have two similar words combined... it just means the same thing as those two words. In this case, the anti-versus of something would be the <vocabulary>opposite</vocabulary>. 

反対 refers to something that's opposite in direction, position, or nature. In some cases, it can also mean <vocabulary>opposition</vocabulary> because disagreeing or resisting to something means someone is taking the opposite side on a matter.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I often see the news on this station.
examples.ja: この局のニュースをよく見ます。

examples.en: You can mail out letters overseas at the post office.
examples.ja: ゆうびん局では海外に手紙を出すことが出来ます。

examples.en: The North American Bureau mainly does diplomacy with the United States and Canada.
examples.ja: 北米局では、主にアメリカとカナダとの外交をします。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The kanji and the vocab are exactly the same, even the reading. This one uses the on'yomi probably because it's often attached to other words (specifying a bureau, for example), so that's why it follows jukugo conventions despite being all alone.

examples.en: Please head back from the Tokyo branch to headquarters in Portland.
examples.ja: 東京支局からポートランドの本社にもどって下さい。

examples.en: Last year, I went to the Tokyo branch of the passport center.
examples.ja: 去年、パスポートセンターの東京支局へ行きました。

examples.en: Does TV Tokyo have overseas bureaus?
examples.ja: テレビ東京には、海外支局はありますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>support</kanji> <kanji>bureau</kanji> is the group that supports a business. It is the <vocabulary>branch office</vocabulary>. 

If it helps, this word has the same meaning as <vocabulary>支店</vocabulary> which you will also be learning in this level.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'll be on a diet for a role.
examples.ja: 役のためにダイエットします。

examples.en: The role of Romeo is Leonardo DiCaprio.
examples.ja: ロミオ役はレオナルド・ディカプリオです。

examples.en: Part-time workers at convenience stores play a more important role in Japanese society than you think.
examples.ja: コンビニのアルバイトは、日本社会にとって、あなたが思ってるよりも大切な役です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a certain <kanji>duty</kanji> then it's your job to play that <vocabulary>role</vocabulary>. You have to play the <vocabulary>part</vocabulary>. Like in a play!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, meaning you should be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: A public official came today.
examples.ja: 今日、役人が来ましたよ。

examples.en: If you graduate from college and pass all tests, you can become a government official.
examples.ja: 大学を出て、全てのテストに通れば、役人になれます。

examples.en: Even the official is a human with a heart.
examples.ja: 役人だって、心のある一人の人間なんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>duty</kanji> this <kanji>person</kanji> has? It's to the government, which makes them a <vocabulary>public official</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>government official</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

A <vocabulary>public official</vocabulary> recently declared that all the <reading>yak</reading>s at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (やくにん) are going to be kicked out. You didn't know that Nintendo has resident yaks? Well it does, but not for much longer. But who will take care of all the Nintendo yaks now?! Maybe you could take one in!

examples.en: Masking tape is useful for various things.
examples.ja: マスキングテープは、色々なことの役に立つ。

examples.en: Yamashita-sensei's advice is helpful for life.
examples.ja: 山下先生の助言は、人生の役に立つ。

examples.en: I'm sorry that I couldn't be much help.
examples.ja: あまりお役に立てず、すみませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: When duty (役) comes calling, those willing to stand (立つ) and accept it are the ones who are going <vocabulary>to be useful</vocabulary> to society. Don't run from your duties — stand up, face them, and prove yourself a useful member of the human race!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 役 is the one you learned with the kanji. The 立つ reading is that of the 立つ vocabulary, which you should be familiar with by now.

examples.en: Being a teacher at this school is a great duty.
examples.ja: この学校の先生になることは、大役ですよ。

examples.en: Thanks to getting a big role in the drama series, I became popular nationwide.
examples.ja: ドラマの大役になったおかげで、全国で人気になりました。

examples.en: Being a leader at the Middle East bureau is an important role!
examples.ja: 中東局でリーダーになるなんて、大役ですよ！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>duty</kanji> is a <vocabulary>great duty</vocabulary>. It can also be an <vocabulary>important task</vocabulary>. Think about some kind of big duty you have. Then, think about what an important task it is too. Feel proud of your important task.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

You've been assigned the <vocabulary>important task</vocabulary> of taking care of the local <reading>tie</reading> <reading>yak</reading>s (たいやく). Where you're from, tie-wearing yaks are incredibly important, so don't take this great duty lightly!

examples.en: This is psychology research.
examples.ja: これは、心理学の研究です。

examples.en: According to research, tea makes people healthy.
examples.ja: 研究によると、お茶は人を元気にします。

examples.en: There was no answer in this investigation.
examples.ja: 今回の研究では答えが出ませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>sharpen</kanji> <kanji>research</kanji> you're just doing a <vocabulary>study</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>investigation</vocabulary>. Or in other words, you're doing <vocabulary>research</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a ball throwing exercise.
examples.ja: これは、ボールを投げるエクササイズです。

examples.en: How far the Frisbee goes depends on the strength of the person who throws it.
examples.ja: フリスビーがどこまで行くかは、投げる人の力によります。

examples.en: It's rude to throw money at people.
examples.ja: 人に向かってお金を投げるのは失礼ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>throw</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to throw</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached, so you can bet it uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're at a baseball game watching people <vocabulary>throw</vocabulary> balls around. But you're hungry so you call for a snack from a vendor. You raise your hand and they throw some <reading>na</reading>chos (な) at you. Oh no! Oh ouch! The nachos are hot and they hit you in the face. The vendor just threw a bunch of hot, sauced nachos at you! WHY?!

examples.en: Let's do yoga every day for your mind and body.
examples.ja: 心身のために毎日ヨガをしましょう。

examples.en: The balance of mind and body is important.
examples.ja: 心身のバランスが大切です。

examples.en: My mind and body were not well so I decided to take a leave of absence.
examples.ja: 心身が元気でなくなってしまい、休学することにしました。

meaning_mnemonic: Technically this kanji is <kanji>heart</kanji> and <kanji>somebody</kanji>, but think about it this way. Where does everything come from inside somebody? The heart! It keeps things going by pumping blood, providing the foundation for both a good <vocabulary>mind and body</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My body is fine, but my heart is tattered.
examples.ja: 身体は元気ですが、心はボロボロですよ。

examples.en: My mother has had a weak constitution since she was born.
examples.ja: 母は生まれた時から身体が弱いんです。

examples.en: Doing sports is important, but resting your body is even more important.
examples.ja: スポーツも大切ですが、身体を休めることはそれ以上に大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Somebody</kanji>'s <kanji>body</kanji>. This refers to the very general word <vocabulary>the body</vocabulary>. As in, "the human body" or something like that. This can also refer to <vocabulary>health</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This word can also be read からだ, which is irregular but shouldn't be too hard to remember because it's the same as the reading you already learned for 体! You'd usually use this reading in casual contexts, and when the word is on its own, rather than in a compound word. In formal situations and compounds, you'd want to stick to the regular old on'yomi reading.

examples.en: Please spray over your whole body once a day.
examples.ja: 一日に一回、全身にスプレーして下さい。

examples.en: Every day, I go to work in a business suit from head to toe.
examples.ja: 毎日、全身ビジネススーツで会社に行きます。

examples.en: I had a lot of red dots throughout my body due to a crab allergy.
examples.ja: カニのアレルギーで全身にたくさんの赤い点が出てしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>all</kanji> of <kanji>somebody</kanji> is someone's <vocabulary>whole body</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are many large trees in this forest.
examples.ja: この森には大きい木がたくさん有ります。

examples.en: Walking in the woods is very fun.
examples.ja: 森の中を歩くのは、とても楽しいです。

examples.en: I want to build a house where you can see the forest.
examples.ja: 森が見える場所に家を作りたいと思っています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too.

examples.en: Both people's thoughts are not the same.
examples.ja: 両者の考えが同じじゃない。

examples.en: With the power of both people, I think you can reach the right answer.
examples.ja: 両者の力で、正しい答えが出せると思うんです。

examples.en: The game ended in a tie, with both sides scoring the same.
examples.ja: そのゲームは、両者同点の引き分けでした。

examples.en: A year and a half later, a deal was finally struck between the two parties.
examples.ja: 一年半後にようやく両者の間で取引が行われた。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>both</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji>s, you have <vocabulary>both people</vocabulary>. You'll notice over time that 者 is often used to indicate a person or type of person, so keep that in mind for future words as well!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to meet the author of this book.
examples.ja: この本の作者に会いたいです。

examples.en: That song is filled with the feelings of the composer.
examples.ja: その曲には作者の思いがこもっています。

examples.en: I heard that the artist graduated from art university and became a macramé artist.
examples.ja: あの作者はアートの大学を出て、マクラメ作家になったそうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Someone</kanji> who <kanji>make</kanji>s is someone who creates things. Back in the day, a creator like this may have been known as many things, but the big one that stands out is an <vocabulary>author</vocabulary>.

Wondering about the difference between 作者 and 作家? Basically, 作者 just refers to the creator of a particular creative work, such as a book, article, artwork, piece of music, etc., while 作家 refers to someone who creates those things as an occupation.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your favorite <vocabulary>author</vocabulary> is also a <reading>sack</reading> <reading>sha</reading>man (さくしゃ). They do all sorts of weird magic involving sacks, and you just love reading about it. Maybe one day, you can become a sack shaman and <vocabulary>writer</vocabulary> yourself.

examples.en: My father is a scholar of psychology.
examples.ja: 父は心理学の学者です。

examples.en: The writer of this book is a famous scholar.
examples.ja: この本の作家は有名な学者です。

examples.en: The scholars are doing research about Hello Kitty every day.
examples.ja: 学者たちは毎日ハローキティについて研究しています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does <kanji>study</kanji> for a living. That is a <vocabulary>scholar</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That man is a famous engineer.
examples.ja: あの男の人は有名な工学者です。

examples.en: Who is the robotics engineer who created the Roomba?
examples.ja: 「ルンバ」を作ったロボット工学者は一体だれですか？

examples.en: Can I become an engineer without going to college?
examples.ja: 大学に行かなくても、工学者になれますか？

meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember 工学 from a couple levels ago? This is <kanji>someone</kanji> who is in 工学. If 工学 is "engineering" then 工学者 is an <vocabulary>engineer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are just the on'yomi readings of the kanji. All things you should know now.

examples.en: This is the spot where the corpse was visible from the soil.
examples.ja: 土の中から死体が見えたのが、この場所です。

examples.en: Excuse me. Could you tell me the location of a nearby ATM?
examples.ja: すみません。近くのATMの場所を教えてくれませんか。

examples.en: Where was the location of your first kiss?
examples.ja: ファーストキスの場所はどこですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>location</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is either a <vocabulary>place</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>location</vocabulary>, just like the kanji it's made from.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi reading for the second. You haven't learned this reading for 場 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What is this <vocabulary>place</vocabulary> you're in? You look around and listen. You hear, "<reading>Baa</reading> (ば) baa baa!" You must be in a <reading>ba</reading>rn!

examples.en: Please buy a ticket before you enter.
examples.ja: 入場する前にチケットを買って下さい。

examples.en: Today's admission is from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.
examples.ja: 今日の入場は、午前十時から午後八時までです。

examples.en: Admission costs 1000 yen.
examples.ja: 入場には千円かかります。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>location</kanji>, that's your <vocabulary>entrance</vocabulary>.

This is a common word for admission into public events or venues, like a concert hall, a sports stadium, or a theme park.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This town has a large factory.
examples.ja: この町には大きな工場があります。

examples.en: Factory staff come to work every day at 6 a.m.
examples.ja: 工場のスタッフは毎日午前六時に出社します。

examples.en: Since I was injured in a wine factory, I only noticed the bleeding a day later.
examples.ja: ワインの工場でケガをしたため、出血に気がつくのが一日後になりました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>construction</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is a <vocabulary>factory</vocabulary>. A factory is a place where you or machines do a bunch of construction!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If there’s a spot you don’t understand, please raise your hand.
examples.ja: 分からない所があれば、手を上げてください。

examples.en: See you at the same place as last time.
examples.ja: 前回と同じ所で会いましょう。

examples.en: My friend came over just as my mother was doing squats.
examples.ja: お母さんがスクワットをしている所に、友人が来てしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Wondering about how 所 differs from 場所? While 場所 only refers to a physical location, 所 can also refer to an abstract place, such as a point in time, a situation, or a condition. Hence, 所 usually needs some context to clarify what kind of place you are talking about.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Here's the <vocabulary>place</vocabulary>! Either you have to <reading>talk or row</reading> (ところ). If you talk, maybe you can talk your way out of this problem you're in. If you row, you may be able to escape. Either way, this is the place for it.

examples.en: Not here, let’s go to another store somewhere else.
examples.ja: ここじゃなくて、どこか他所の店に行こうよ。

examples.en: Their house, their rules. Our house, our rules.
examples.ja: 他所は他所、家は家！

examples.en: My mother is from around here. Don't say she's a person from somewhere else.
examples.ja: 私の母はこの辺の生まれです。他所の人間だなんて言わないで下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: When you're talking about some <kanji>other</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> you're talking about <vocabulary>another place</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which you would normally expect to use the on'yomi readings from the kanji. With this word, however, the on'yomi readings are rarely used now, so they sound rather out of date. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the more common reading in contemporary Japanese:

Another place <reading>you saw</reading> (よそ) always seems better. In other words, the grass is greener somewhere else you saw!

examples.en: Tokyo Tower is one of Japan's famous places.
examples.ja: 東京タワーは、日本の名所の一つです。

examples.en: Are there any famous spots you recommend around here?
examples.ja: この辺に、おすすめの名所は有りますか？

examples.en: This town is a famous spot for cherry blossom viewing.
examples.ja: この町は、花見の名所です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>famous</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is a <vocabulary>famous place</vocabulary>. When traveling around Japan, you should ask about the 名所 if you can.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Next, please enter your address.
examples.ja: 次に、住所を入力して下さい。

examples.en: I'd like to mail out a letter, but can you tell me the address of the house?
examples.ja: 手紙を出したいんですが、家の住所を教えてもらえませんか？

examples.en: The address of the company is 3-chome.
examples.ja: 会社の住所は三丁目です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>dwell</kanji> in a <kanji>place</kanji>, that place is your <vocabulary>address</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word is made up of the on'yomi readings that you've already learned with the kanji. Have at it!

examples.en: It's already morning.
examples.ja: もう朝ですよ。

examples.en: In the morning before going to work, we have coffee and tea.
examples.ja: 朝、出社する前にコーヒーとお茶をのみます。

examples.en: I went to a popular bakery early in the morning.
examples.ja: 人気のベーカリーに朝早く行きました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Hopefully this means you won't have to wake up too early in the morning to study kanji, now.

examples.en: My breakfast everyday is bacon and bread.
examples.ja: 毎日の朝ごはんはベーコンとパンです。

examples.en: I always go to work without eating breakfast.
examples.ja: 私はいつも朝ごはんを食べずに出社します。

examples.en: After breakfast, I run.
examples.ja: 朝ごはんの後、ランニングをします。

meaning_mnemonic: ごはん is a food or meal (maybe you'll learn the kanji for it later, but it's not usually used, so you're learning it this way now). What is your <kanji>morning</kanji> meal? That is <vocabulary>breakfast</vocabulary> (not to be confused with second breakfast, you hobbit).
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 朝 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read everything here.

examples.en: I do yoga in the bright morning sunshine.
examples.ja: 明るい朝日の中、ヨガをします。

examples.en: The rising sun seen from the mountain is very beautiful.
examples.ja: 山の上から見る朝日は、とてもキレイです。

examples.en: Morning sunlight and birdsong don't wake me, so I make sure to set my alarm before going to bed.
examples.ja: 朝日と鳥の声では目がさめないので、ベッドに行く前にアラームは必ずセットします。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>morning</kanji> <kanji>sun</kanji> is not only the <vocabulary>morning sun</vocabulary>, but it's the <vocabulary>rising sun</vocabulary> as well (because that's when the sun rises, right?).
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which is convenient since you've learned both of them by now with the words 朝 (あさ) and 日 (ひ). Put them together and what do you get? あさひ!

examples.en: Please tell me the ticket number.
examples.ja: チケット番号を教えて下さい。

examples.en: My student number is 4890.
examples.ja: 私の学生番号は４８９０です。

examples.en: Tanaka-san's phone number is in my smartphone.
examples.ja: 田中さんの電話番号はスマホに入ってます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>number in a series</kanji> plus a <kanji>number</kanji>. You know what happens when two kanji with basically the same meaning get combined into one by now, right? It just turns out to be the same meaning, basically. This word means <vocabulary>number</vocabulary>, and it's used in contexts like phone numbers, exam numbers, and serial numbers.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The most important thing to me is money.
examples.ja: 私にとって一番大切なのはお金です。

examples.en: I want to get the highest score on this week's test.
examples.ja: 今週のテストで一番高い点数をとりたいです。

examples.en: This is the most popular song in all of America right now.
examples.ja: これが、今全米で一番人気の曲ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you're the number <kanji>one</kanji> in a <kanji>number in a series</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>number one</vocabulary> ba-bay!

This word can refer to something ranked <vocabulary>first</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>best</vocabulary> in comparison to other things, or it can specifically refer to something marked with the number one, like an athlete with the number one on their jersey.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am entry number two.
examples.ja: 私はエントリーナンバー二番です。

examples.en: Today is the second-longest day of the year.
examples.ja: 今日は一年の中で二番に長い日です。

examples.en: We won second place in the high school regatta.
examples.ja: 高校のボートレースで二番になりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you're number <kanji>two</kanji> in a <kanji>number in a series</kanji> you're <vocabulary>number two</vocabulary>. Not quite as good as being 一番, but take what you can get, you know?

This word can refer to something ranked <vocabulary>second</vocabulary> in comparison to other things, or it can specifically refer to something marked with the number two, like an athlete with the number two on their jersey.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There were a lot of German shepherds in front of the police box.
examples.ja: 交番の前に、たくさんのジャーマンシェパードがいました。

examples.en: Grandma, who always loses her way home, is a heavy user of the police box.
examples.ja: いつも家までの道が分からなくなってしまうおばあちゃんは、交番のヘビーユーザーです。

examples.en: Ironically, I feel uneasy if there's a police box too close to my house.
examples.ja: 皮肉なことに、家から交番が近すぎると、反対に不安です。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word is a little tricky — at first, the combination of <kanji>mix</kanji> and <kanji>number in a series</kanji> doesn't seem to add up to <vocabulary>police box</vocabulary>, but there's a catch. This word is actually an abbreviated combo of two other words: The 交 comes from 交替 (in rotation) and the 番 comes from 立番 (standing watch).

A <vocabulary>police box</vocabulary> is basically a tiny community police station staffed by one or two officers. It's something that is not common in many Western countries, but it is pretty much all over Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The correct answer of "three plus four" is "seven."
examples.ja: 「三足す四」の正しい答えは「七」です。

examples.en: Please pick an answer from A, B, C or D.
examples.ja: 答えは、A・B・C・Dの中から、えらんで下さい。

examples.en: I don't know the answer, so I'll get advice from the teacher.
examples.ja: 答えが分からないので、先生に助言をもらいます。

meaning_mnemonic: You can guess this is a noun version of the kanji because the hiragana sticking out of it isn't an う-related sound or an い-related sound. So, what is the noun version of <kanji>answer</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi, but this is also the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this and then give your 答え correctly.

examples.en: It took a little time to answer "yes."
examples.ja: 「はい」と答えるのに少し時間がかかった。

examples.en: In return for answering the questionnaire, I got ice cream.
examples.ja: アンケートに答えた代わりに、アイスクリームをもらいました。

examples.en: When I answer the phone, I first answer "hello" and say my name.
examples.ja: 私は電話に出る時、先ず「もしもし」と答えて、自分の名前を言います。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>answer</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to answer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading as you'd expect with all the hiragana, but luckily that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: This is a famous Picasso painting.
examples.ja: これは有名なピカソの絵です。

examples.en: I paint pictures in the street on my days off.
examples.ja: 私は休日に道で絵をかいてます。

examples.en: To not have a single picture in your house, are you like a serial killer or something?
examples.ja: 家に絵が一つもないなんて、あなたはシリアルキラーか何かですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

絵 refers to <vocabulary>picture</vocabulary>s, such as <vocabulary>painting</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>drawing</vocabulary>s, or <vocabulary>illustration</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I'm buying coffee at the convenience store in the morning today as well.
examples.ja: 今日も朝、コンビニでコーヒーを買う。

examples.en: I always buy extra toilet paper so that we don't run out on weekdays.
examples.ja: トイレットペーパーは平日に切れないよう、いつも多めに買います。

examples.en: I bought both my car and my house used.
examples.ja: 車も家も中古で買いました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>buy</kanji> so the verb form is <vocabulary>to buy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be just fine.

examples.en: My father jogs on this street every morning.
examples.ja: 父は毎朝、この道でジョギングをします。

examples.en: I walked desperately down a long road and came to Tokyo.
examples.ja: 必死に長い道を歩いて東京に来たんです。

examples.en: Hollywood has a road with many celebrity names on it.
examples.ja: ハリウッドには、多くの有名人の名前が入った道があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

Don't confuse this with the word 〜道, though. This one doesn't have a 〜 at the beginning, meaning it's not attached to other words. This word is just plain old road. It has its own meaning!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You're walking down the road. On the <vocabulary>road</vocabulary>, you bump into your friend, <reading>Mitch</reading> (みち). Imagine saying hello, then continuing down the road. What's weird is you're both walking down a paved road with cars on it. Seems dangerous, but you and Mitch, you know what you're doing. 

If you don't know anyone named Mitch, think of a famous Mitch or a Mitch you've made up.

examples.en: This sidewalk is wide and easy to walk on.
examples.ja: この歩道は広くて歩きやすいです。

examples.en: Cars should never run on the sidewalk.
examples.ja: 車は決して歩道を走らないで下さい。

examples.en: Can a Segway run on the sidewalk?
examples.ja: セグウェイは歩道を走ってもいいんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>road</kanji> you <kanji>walk</kanji> on is the <vocabulary>sidewalk</vocabulary>... at least I hope that's where you walk.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: On my days off, I go to tea ceremony lessons.
examples.ja: 休みの日は、茶道の教室に行きます。

examples.en: Judo is a martial art from Japan.
examples.ja: じゅう道は日本生まれのマーシャルアーツです。

examples.en: Kendo swords are made of bamboo.
examples.ja: 剣道の刀は竹で出来ています。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a word that's attached to the end of various other words. Think of a "road" as a <vocabulary>way</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>method of</vocabulary> something. For example, the どう in Judo is the soft "way." There are many words that end with 道, and you'll see them later on. For now, know that this means <vocabulary>method of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>way</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word is added to the end of many different words, meaning it's treated like most jukugo (and uses an on'yomi reading). You know the on'yomi reading, so you should be able to read this word. Be sure to drop the 〜 when writing in the reading in the test, though. It's only there to show that it's added onto things and not part of the correct answer.

examples.en: While I'm at school, I turn my smartphone off.
examples.ja: 学校にいる間は、スマホを切っています。

examples.en: While my father was buying coffee at a convenience store, I was in the car.
examples.ja: 父がコンビニでコーヒーを買っている間、私は車内にいました。

examples.en: I want to think about my life during my leave of absence.
examples.ja: 休学の間、人生についてよく考えたいと思っています。

examples.en: I was chatting with a friend in the living room, and before I knew it, it was six o'clock.
examples.ja: 友人とお茶の間で話していると、あっという間に６時になっていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

Don't confuse this with 〜間 which is similar in meaning but different in reading. The 〜間 means it's attached to something. This is a standalone word.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. 間 has two common kun'yomi readings, あいだ and ま. You haven't learned these readings yet, so here's an explanation of each reading and mnemonics to help you remember them:

間 is usually read as あいだ for a longer interval of time or general space between things. It's read as ま for a short burst of time or when defining a specific area, like a 茶の間 (the older name for a Japanese living room).

You can remember this because time feels longer in <reading>Ida</reading>ho (あいだ). Any interval of time you spend there feels so long, because Idaho life moves so slowly. As soon as you cross the border and enter a new state, you call your <reading>ma</reading> (ま) to tell her you're finally out of that slooooow state, and the intervals of time feel shorter.

examples.en: One more day until the JLPT. I don't have enough time.
examples.ja: JLPTまで、あと一日。時間が足りません。

examples.en: In this holiday, I have plenty of time to play games.
examples.ja: 今回の休みは、ゲームをする時間がたくさんあります。

examples.en: I work every day on weekdays, but I have a good time with my friends on weekends.
examples.ja: 平日は毎日仕事ですが、週末には友人と楽しい時間をすごします。

examples.en: It took three whole hours by bus to get to Disneyland.
examples.ja: ディズニーランドまで、バスで３時間もかかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>interval of time</kanji> is just the <vocabulary>time</vocabulary>. As is often the case, if two similar meaning kanji are combined into one word, they tend to produce a word with a similar meaning. Excuse me, friend, what's the 時間?

Note that 時間 can also be used as a unit of time measurement to mean <vocabulary>hour</vocabulary>(s). In this case, it's always used as a suffix — usually following a number or the question word 何 (なん).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You can go to convenience stores anytime, twenty-four hours a day.
examples.ja: コンビニは２４時間いつでも行くことが出来ます。

examples.en: The dollar increased by thirty yen in one year.
examples.ja: 一年間でドルが三十円も上がりました。

examples.en: Can you let me be in the bathroom for only three minutes?
examples.ja: 三分間だけ、トイレにいさせてくれませんか？

meaning_mnemonic:
When you stick this onto the end of another word that talks about an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> in some way, you're indicating the <vocabulary>amount of time</vocabulary> that has gone past. For example, 二年間 is "two years." 一時間 is "one hour." Any amount of time + 〜間 will make it an "amount of time" instead of just a specific time.

Note that 〜間 can be omitted, especially in conversations, when it's clear that you're talking about a duration of time from the context. However, the exception is 時. You always say 〜時間 to refer to the amount of hours, to differentiate from 〜時 (〜o'clock).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. This should save you at least 二分間.

examples.en: Humans are mainly made of water.
examples.ja: 人間は主に水で出来ています。

examples.en: This is a hair dryer for humans, right?
examples.ja: これは人間用のヘアドライヤーですよね？

examples.en: I have concerns about whether I can be independent and do well in human society.
examples.ja: 人間社会で自立して上手くやっていくのに不安が有ります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji>. Just think of different intervals each with a different type of species. The raccoon interval... the dog interval... the person interval... they are the <vocabulary>human</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, and the reading of 間 is a bit of an oddball, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Did you know that the <vocabulary>human</vocabulary>s who work for <reading>Nin</reading>tendo are all called <reading>Gen</reading>ji (にんげん)? Yep, that's right, every single human ever hired by Nintendo is called Genji, without exception.

examples.en: It will be open soon!
examples.ja: 間もなくオープンです！

examples.en: I heard the classroom door, so I thought the teacher would come in soon.
examples.ja: 教室のドアの音がしたので、間もなく先生が入ってくるかと思った。

examples.en: Breakfast will be ready soon, so please put spoons and forks on the table.
examples.ja: 間もなく朝ごはんが出来ますから、テーブルの上にスプーンとフォークを出して下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
The もなく part is like saying "there isn't even." So, when "there isn't even <kanji>an interval of time</kanji>," things will happen <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>before long</vocabulary>.

You'll probably hear this the most in train announcements letting you know your train will <vocabulary>shortly</vocabulary> be arriving in Tokyo or wherever.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this one is weird, though. It's a second kun'yomi reading (there is also あいだ), read as ま. So what is happening <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>? Your <reading>Ma</reading> is going to be here <vocabulary>before long</vocabulary>. You better hurry and prepare, because your room looks terrible... 

"間もなく, your mom is about to show up!"

examples.en: Your own house is a safe space where you can relax.
examples.ja: 自分の家は安心できる空間の一つです。

examples.en: I can't be in the same space as a dog because I'm allergic.
examples.ja: アレルギーなので犬と同じ空間にいることが出来ません。

examples.en: At university, I learned spatial design.
examples.ja: 大学では、空間デザインを学びました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is an area of the sky. In places that are just empty sky, there is only <vocabulary>space</vocabulary>. Of course, not technically... there's something there, but back in the day when kanji was being made, nobody knew that. This word can mean both space in regards to outer space as well as the space around you in your room.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Clouds are white and they're like cotton.
examples.ja: 雲は、白くてコットンみたいですよね。

examples.en: Today, there was no sunlight because of the clouds.
examples.ja: 今日は、雲のせいで日光がありませんでした。

examples.en: There was not a cloud in the blue summer sky.
examples.ja: 夏の青空には、雲一つありませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading because it's a single kanji on its own. Luckily, that's the reading you learned with the kanji already, so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: My father counts sheep in bed every night.
examples.ja: 父は毎日夜になるとベッドの中で羊を数える。

examples.en: On our last date, we counted the balloons we could see in the blue sky together.
examples.ja: 前回のデートでは、二人で青空に見える風船を数えた。

examples.en: The teacher counted the number of students in the classroom at the time.
examples.ja: 先生はその時教室にいた学生の数を数えました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>count</kanji>, so obviously the verb version is <vocabulary>to count</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You begin <vocabulary>to count</vocabulary> vocabulary words. You're out of control and you can't stop. One after another. Scientists have to come in, but they can't figure out the <reading>cause</reading> (かぞ) of your counting. They drag you away to a padded cell where they keep testing you trying to figure out the cause of your craziness.

examples.en: What is the number of tomatoes in this soup?
examples.ja: このスープに入ってるトマトの数は？

examples.en: This time, the number of deaths was the same as last time.
examples.ja: 今回、死亡した人の数は前回と同じでした。

examples.en: In Japan, the number of babies being born is decreasing.
examples.ja: 日本では、生まれる赤ちゃんの数が下がっている。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word is used to say things like "a high number" and "the number of students".
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Imagine yourself <vocabulary>count</vocabulary>ing by playing a <reading>kazoo</reading> (かず). Each number you count, you toot your kazoo. How fun!

examples.en: I'm not good at entering numbers.
examples.ja: 数字を入力するのが下手です。

examples.en: Looking at the numbers, I just remembered the answer.
examples.ja: その数字を見て、答えを思い出しました。

examples.en: The shape of the Arabic numeral 8 is my favorite.
examples.ja: アラビア数字の８の形が、一番すきです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>number</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji> isn't a letter like the ones you're reading now, it's more like a <vocabulary>numeral</vocabulary>, like 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My mother was a high school math teacher.
examples.ja: 母は高校の数学の先生でした。

examples.en: I'm very worried about tomorrow's math test.
examples.ja: 明日の数学のテスト、すごく不安なんですよ。

examples.en: Are the math answers correct?
examples.ja: その数学の答えは正しいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>study</kanji> of <kanji>number</kanji>s is <vocabulary>mathematics</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>math</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The number of staff at this company is twenty people.
examples.ja: この会社のスタッフの人数は二十人です。

examples.en: The number of people coming to work has dropped a little this week.
examples.ja: 今週の出社人数は少し下がった。

examples.en: There weren't enough staff at last year's event, but this year there are too many.
examples.ja: 去年のイベントではスタッフの人数が足りなかったのに、今年は多すぎるくらいです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>count</kanji> is <vocabulary>the number of people</vocabulary>. Don't confuse this with the "population" or something like that, though. This is more like "how many people are at this event?" What's the 人数, you know?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Note that rendaku turns すう into ずう, and since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Do you know <vocabulary>the number of people</vocabulary> at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (にん)? It's a big mystery, which is why they hired you to count every single one of them. Good luck!

examples.en: The score this time was 100 points.
examples.ja: 今回の点数は百点でした。

examples.en: My younger brother didn't tell me his test score.
examples.ja: 弟はテストの点数を教えてくれなかった。

examples.en: My older sister suggested that I give my teacher some donuts to raise my math score.
examples.ja: 姉には、数学の点数を上げるために、先生にドーナッツをあげたら？と助言された。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>point</kanji>s is how many <vocabulary>points</vocabulary> there are (aka the <vocabulary>score</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Walking with a dog is fun.
examples.ja: 犬と歩くのは楽しい。

examples.en: It was fun seeing fireworks with my friends when I was a college student.
examples.ja: 大学生の時、友人と花火を見たのが楽しかったです。

examples.en: It's more fun to eat breakfast while watching TV than it is to eat while talking to someone.
examples.ja: 朝ごはんは、テレビを見ながら食べる方が、人と話しながら食べるより楽しいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Ending with an い tells you that this word is an い-adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pleasure</kanji>? Well, you could say it's "pleasurable," but I'm afraid that's not what we're going for here. In this case, this word is a little more innocent. It just means <vocabulary>fun</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

How much <vocabulary>fun</vocabulary> did you have? You just had a <reading>ton o'</reading> (たの) fun!

examples.en: There will be a big music event tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日、大きな音楽のイベントがあります。

examples.en: Could you turn up the music volume a little more?
examples.ja: もう少し音楽のボリュームを上げてもらえませんか？

examples.en: I like the music of Takeuchi Mariya and Yamashita Tatsurō.
examples.ja: 竹内まりやと山下タツロウの音楽が気に入っています。

meaning_mnemonic: What is the <kanji>sound</kanji> of <kanji>pleasure</kanji>? What <kanji>sound</kanji> puts you at <kanji>ease</kanji>? For most people that is some nice <vocabulary>music</vocabulary>. Just be sure you don't put on any Bieber... that would be like 不音楽 or something... I kid, I kid.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 楽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you play your <vocabulary>music</vocabulary> too loud, people will come and <reading>gawk</reading> (がく) at you. But if you try to turn it off and say, "OH I DON'T LIKE MUSIC ANYWAY!" they'll gawk at you even more. Learn proper music etiquette and people won't gawk at you so much, okay?

examples.en: This sofa is really comfortable.
examples.ja: このソファは本当に楽ですね。

examples.en: After buying a car, it became easy to go to the company.
examples.ja: 車を買ってから、会社に行くのが楽になりました。

examples.en: I feel at ease thinking that there won't be school after the test.
examples.ja: テストの後は休みだと思うと気が楽です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, too, making this one an <vocabulary>ease</vocabulary> to learn!

examples.en: I rarely talk to others on the street.
examples.ja: 道で他人と話すことは、ほぼありません。

examples.en: At this meeting, we mainly talked about American beef.
examples.ja: 今回のミーティングでは、主に米国の牛肉のことを話しました。

examples.en: Every day, I talk to a friend over the phone after dinner.
examples.ja: 毎日、ディナーの後に電話で友人と話します。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>talk</kanji> so the verb version of this is <vocabulary>to talk</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to speak</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Every time you try <vocabulary>to speak</vocabulary>, <reading>花</reading>s (はな) just sprout out of your mouth preventing you. Imagine your mouth full of flowers. Taste them, spit them out, and try to speak again. Same problem.

examples.en: It's a phone call from Yamashita-sensei.
examples.ja: 山下先生から電話です。

examples.en: I told my mother "thank you" on the phone.
examples.ja: 電話で「ありがとう」とお母さんに言いました。

examples.en: That's not the right phone number.
examples.ja: それ、正しい電話番号ではないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji>. What is this witchcraft? The only way to talk via electricity is with a <vocabulary>telephone</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a recording of a conversation with Nicolas Cage.
examples.ja: これはニコラス・ケイジ氏との会話のレコーディングです。

examples.en: I learned psychology in my conversations with many people.
examples.ja: 多くの人々との会話の中で心理学を学びました。

examples.en: If you say something rude in a conversation with a friend, it's important to say "sorry" immediately.
examples.ja: 友人との会話で、失礼なことを言ってしまったときは、すぐに「ごめん」と言うことが大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>meet</kanji> and <kanji>talk</kanji> with someone else, you're having a <vocabulary>conversation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Does that red train go to Tokyo?
examples.ja: あの赤い電車は、東京まで行きますか？

examples.en: Cameras for taking pictures of trains are quite expensive.
examples.ja: 電車を写す用のカメラは、中々高いですよ。

examples.en: Please look at this paper for a schedule of morning train times.
examples.ja: 朝の電車の時間のスケジュールは、この紙を見て下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: You would think that an <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji> was an electric car, but this word was made before the days of the Prius. This refers to a <vocabulary>train</vocabulary>, which I guess was electric at some point.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please turn the light on.
examples.ja: 電気を点けて下さい。

examples.en: When the lights are on, it's a sign that staff are in the office.
examples.ja: 会社の電気が明るい時は、スタッフが出社しているサインです。

examples.en: In winter, we use an electric heater.
examples.ja: 冬は、電気のストーブを用います。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Electricity</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is just a fancy way to say <vocabulary>electricity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The battery of the smartphone has run out.
examples.ja: スマホの電池が切れた。

examples.en: There is no battery in this radio.
examples.ja: このラジオ、電池が入ってないよ。

examples.en: This battery is too big.
examples.ja: この電池は大きすぎます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>pond</kanji> for <kanji>electricity</kanji>? May seem weird at first, but if you think of something that's gathering all the electricity into one pond... that thing is like a <vocabulary>battery</vocabulary> (and is a battery).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I put the curry in the microwave.
examples.ja: カレーを電子レンジに入れました。

examples.en: How much does that electronic piano cost?
examples.ja: その電子ピアノはいくらですか。

examples.en: A year ago, I started reading e-books on my Kindle instead of paper books.
examples.ja: 一年前から、紙の本ではなく、Kindleで電子ブックをよむようになりました。

examples.en: You can't see electrons with your eyes.
examples.ja: 電子は目で見ることができません。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji>. What is a really small part of electricity? What makes up electricity? That would be the <vocabulary>electron</vocabulary>. This word can also refer to things that are <vocabulary>electronic</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There is a shortage of electricity nationwide now.
examples.ja: 全国で今、電力が不足しています。

examples.en: The power went out and the electricity stopped.
examples.ja: 電力が切れて、電気が止まってしまった。

examples.en: As for the electricity company around here, it’s the Tokyo Electric Power Company.
examples.ja: この辺の電力会社と言えば、東京電力ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> of something is its <vocabulary>electric power</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

All the world's <vocabulary>electric power</vocabulary> is stored behind this <reading>lock</reading> (りょく). Go ahead. Open it up. What could possibly go wrong?

examples.en: Today's game was a tie.
examples.ja: 今日のゲームは引き分けだった。

examples.en: Even when it actually was a draw, in my heart you're the best in Japan.
examples.ja: 本当は引き分けでも、私の心の中では、あなたが日本一です。

examples.en: A draw means that both teams had the same score.
examples.ja: 引き分けとは、両方のチームが同じ点だったということです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>pull</kanji> something and "separate" (分ける) it, you are making everything even. In a game, this would be a <vocabulary>tie</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>draw</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: See the hiragana stuck in there? That's hinting that these use the kun'yomi readings. You learned the kun'yomi readings of these two kanji separately in the previous level, so if you know those you should know this word's reading as well.

examples.en: Tokyo is a big town.
examples.ja: 東京は大きい町です。

examples.en: You can see the Tokyo Tower from my office.
examples.ja: 私の会社から東京タワーは見えますよ。

examples.en: I'm going from Hawaii to Tokyo.
examples.ja: ハワイから東京に行きます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>East</kanji> <kanji>capital</kanji> in Japan is <vocabulary>Tokyo</vocabulary>. If you look on a map and compare it to Kyoto (the old capital), you'll see it lies to the east. That's why this is the east capital, Tokyo.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 東 (とう) with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help:

How do you know you've made it to <vocabulary>Tokyo</vocabulary>? The station platform signs will say 東京 — <reading>とう</reading>きょう — Tokyo. Just look for those とうきょう signs if you're headed for the east capital.

examples.en: What can you see on the other side of the mountains?
examples.ja: 山の向こうには何が見えますか？

examples.en: Let's buy two loaves of bread at the bakery on the other side of the road.
examples.ja: 道の向こうのベーカリーでパンを二斤買いましょう。

examples.en: When I go abroad, I'm inspired by the culture over there every time.
examples.ja: 海外に行くと、毎回向こうの文化にインスパイアされるんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 向 means <kanji>yonder</kanji>, and this is its noun version, meaning <vocabulary>over there</vocabulary>.

向こう is used when speaking generally about something distant from yourself, whether it's a place, as in 向こうの山 (the mountain <vocabulary>over that way</vocabulary>), or a person, as in 向こうの人 (the person on the <vocabulary>other side</vocabulary>). Sometimes, it can even be used for time, like 向こう一週間 (the next week ahead).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that with 向く, but here's a mnemonic for you in case you forgot:

<vocabulary>Over there</vocabulary>, a cow is saying <reading>moo</reading> (む). It's way over there, though, so you can't see or hear it. Kinda makes you wonder: if a cow moos way over there and no one's around to listen, did it really moo at all?

examples.en: This is a popular blockbuster in all of America.
examples.ja: これは、全米で人気の大作です。

examples.en: What is the number one song on the US hit chart now?
examples.ja: 今、全米ヒットチャートでナンバーワンの曲は何ですか？

examples.en: An interview offer came from a nationwide television station.
examples.ja: 全米のテレビ局から、インタビューのオファーが来た。

meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember how 米国 can mean "America?" That 米 means America sometimes. So, when you see <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>rice</kanji> (I mean, <kanji>America</kanji>), you can think of this word as meaning <vocabulary>All America</vocabulary> (sort of like how 全日本 means "All Japan.").
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I wrote an essay from my summer memories.
examples.ja: 夏の思い出を作文にしました。

examples.en: Memories from when I was little are still precious.
examples.ja: 小さかった時の思い出は、今でも大切です。

examples.en: I'm going to say "goodbye" to memories with my former partner.
examples.ja: 元パートナーとの思い出に「さようなら」を言いたいと思います。

meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember the word 思う? It means "to think." What you are <kanji>think</kanji>ing is <kanji>exit</kanji>ing—it's coming out of your head! You're recalling <vocabulary>a memory</vocabulary> or multiple <vocabulary>memories</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi, but based off of previous experience with the two separate words that make up this word, you should be able to read it. Just remember that it's kun'yomi. One hint is the hiragana sticking out of the 思.

examples.en: Don't get any closer to the river!
examples.ja: それ以上、川に近づくな！

examples.en: This dog gets up and says "woof!" if an adult man approaches him.
examples.ja: この犬は、大人の男が近づくと、立ち上って「ワン！」と言います。

examples.en: Next week, a typhoon will be approaching Kyushu.
examples.ja: 来週、九州に台風が近づきます。

meaning_mnemonic: Because this word ends with an う sound, you can tell it's probably a verb. The kanji portion means <kanji>near</kanji>. The verb version of that is <vocabulary>to draw near</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get close</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to approach</vocabulary>. Essentially, the general idea is that you're getting closer to something. You're becoming more nearby. You're approaching.
reading_mnemonic: There's hiragana attached to this kanji, which means it's probably the kun'yomi reading (and it is). You've seen the kun'yomi reading via the word 近い. So, as long as you know that word, you should be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: I sometimes remember the day when I was proposed to.
examples.ja: たまにプロポーズされた日のことを思い出す。

examples.en: I finally remembered the name of the psychology teacher.
examples.ja: やっと心理学の先生の名前を思い出した。

examples.en: Coming to this area reminds me of when I was small.
examples.ja: この辺りに来ると、小さかった時を思い出します。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 思う means "to think" and 出す means "to take out." So this is what happens when your brain takes a moment to think and pulls a memory out of storage. It means <vocabulary>to remember</vocabulary>!

You can shout 思い出した！when you recall your keys are in the fridge. (Again?!) You can also say 母を思い出します when something reminds you of your mom. In Japanese, you usually omit what reminded you of the memory because the important thing is the memory itself, filling your heart with touchy-feelies. Oh, mama!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi readings. You should know the words 思う and 出す and their readings, so you should be able to read this word if you know those words.

examples.en: Mr. Tanaka is off, so a substitute teacher will come.
examples.ja: 田中先生はお休みなので、代わりの先生が来ます。

examples.en: I got onions in return for giving tomatoes.
examples.ja: トマトをあげた代わりに玉ねぎをもらった。

examples.en: I had a hard time finding a substitute person.
examples.ja: 代わりの人は中々見つからなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that 代わる means "to substitute for" or "to replace." This is the noun version of that (no う sound on the end). So, what is the noun version of those verb words? It would be <vocabulary>substitute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>replacement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You should be able to figure out the reading from learning 代わる in the previous level.

examples.en: I have the exact same idea as you.
examples.ja: あなたと全く同じ考えです。

examples.en: There's no weekdays off at all.
examples.ja: 平日は全く休みが有りません。

examples.en: I pulled the lever with all my strength, but there was no water coming out.
examples.ja: 全力でレバーを引いたが、水は全く出なかった。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>all</kanji>. So, it's like you add an 'ly' to it. But, that doesn't work too well (allly? c'mon). So, instead think of this word as <vocabulary>completely</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>entirely</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>truly</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The person who <vocabulary>completely</vocabulary> doesn't understand this vocab word is <reading>Matt</reading> (まった). Be sure to take note of the small っ, too.

examples.en: The length of this bamboo is three meters.
examples.ja: この竹の長さは三メートルです。

examples.en: About how long is one meeting?
examples.ja: 一回のミーティングの長さは大体どのくらいですか？
