examples.en: The length of this banana is twenty centimeters.
examples.ja: このバナナの長さは、二十センチです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the word 長い from a couple levels ago. This is like the word 大きい versus 大きさ, where 大きさ is "size" and 大きい is "big." So, 長い is "long" and 長さ is <vocabulary>length</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know the reading of the word 長い from level 6 you'll know the reading for this word too. Only difference is the さ at the end, which is hiragana so it should be easy to read.

examples.en: The other day, there was a caterpillar on the tree.
examples.ja: この前、木の上に毛虫がいたんです。

examples.en: Until recently, there were flowers, plants, and shiitake mushrooms growing here.
examples.ja: この前までは、ここには花や草やシイタケが生えてたんです。

examples.en: That woman was on a TV show the other day.
examples.ja: この前のテレビ番組に、あの女の人が出てました。

meaning_mnemonic: この means "this", and you know what the word 前  means (front/before). The combination of these words, "this before" if you will, can mean a few different things. If we're talking about when something happened, the "before" meaning kicks in, and it means <vocabulary>the other day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>. If we're talking about location, then the "front" meaning kicks in, and it means <vocabulary>in front of this</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 前 is the kun'yomi, like the reading for the vocabulary word 前. So long as you know that word, you'll be able to read this one too. The reason it's not on'yomi is because it's like two words put together. The word この and the word 前.

examples.en: There was a flier in the mailbox.
examples.ja: お知らせの紙がポストに入ってました。

examples.en: There's a notice. Please come to the head office right away.
examples.ja: お知らせがあります。今すぐ本社に来てください。

examples.en: And now a word from our sponsor.
examples.ja: ここでスポンサーからのお知らせです。

examples.en: It was announced that the fireworks had been cancelled due to rain.
examples.ja: 雨で花火が中止になったというお知らせがありました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a strange word, so you'll have to bear with me. You know that 知 means <kanji>know</kanji>. But in the case of this word, what do you know? Look at the second half. らせ sounds a bit like "race." So, you know about a "race." How do you know about this race? You got a <vocabulary>notice</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>notification</vocabulary> about it.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already with the kanji, so you should be all set. Lucky you!

examples.en: Next, please tell me your name.
examples.ja: 次に、名前を教えて下さい。

examples.en: My name is Yamada.
examples.ja: 私の名前は山田です。

examples.en: Tofugu is the name of the company that makes WaniKani.
examples.ja: トーフグは、ワニカニを作っている会社の名前です。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>name</kanji> that's in the <kanji>front</kanji>. That is not your last name, that is your regular <vocabulary>name</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>first name</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses both kun'yomi readings (oh darn!). That being said, you've seen the kun'yomi readings for both the kanji that make up this word. The word 名 (な) and the word 前 (まえ) both are kun'yomi, so use those words and Voltron them into a single word, なまえ.

examples.en: It took three days for the crafts to be completed.
examples.ja: 工作が出来上がるのに、三日かかりました。

examples.en: Tea will be ready in about five minutes.
examples.ja: お茶は大体五分で出来上がります。

examples.en: The house will be completed at the end of the month.
examples.ja: 家は月末に出来上がります。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word 出来る (to be able to do), which is the first part. Then the second part, 上がる means "to rise." So, think about it this way: once you're able to do something, you rise because you're finished. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be finished</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of the readings from 出来る and 上がる. So long as you were paying attention in lessons past, you should be able to read this word as well just by combining those other words.

examples.en: Next is a stretch where you bend your ankles.
examples.ja: 次は、足首を曲げるストレッチです。

examples.en: I accidentally bent my father's precious sword.
examples.ja: 父の大切な刀を曲げてしまった。

examples.en: In this YouTube video, Koichi just keeps bending a hundred spoons.
examples.ja: このYouTubeビデオでは、コウイチがスプーンを百本ひたすら曲げつづけます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a verb because it ends with an う sound. What does the kanji mean? It's <kanji>music</kanji> and <kanji>bend</kanji>. In the case of this word, we're going with the "bend" version. The verb of that is <vocabulary>to bend</vocabulary>. This is when you're doing the bending. You can remember this because げ kind of looks like the <reading>ge</reading>cko you're bending. That gecko looked good before you bent him in half.
reading_mnemonic: How were you able <vocabulary>to bend</vocabulary> this gecko? Solo effort? No way! It actually took both you and your <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま) to make it happen! Just imagine you and your mighty mama, tag-teaming to bend a gecko in half!

examples.en: Black hair is mixed in with the white hair.
examples.ja: 白い毛の中に黒い毛が交じる。

examples.en: Some wool yarn was mixed in with the sandwich I bought at the convenience store.
examples.ja: コンビニで買ったサンドイッチに毛糸が交じっていた。

examples.en: Today I live among many Japanese people.
examples.ja: たくさんの日本人の中に交じって今日も生きています。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 交ぜる means <vocabulary>to mix</vocabulary> and that the kanji means <kanji>mix</kanji> as well. So, this probably has something to do with mixing things. This word means <vocabulary>to be mixed</vocabulary>. This is when something is mixed but it's not mixed by you. It's just being mixed. Think of it this way - the じ in 交じる is Jesus, who just uses Jesus magic to mix something. So, you're not mixing it. It's just when something is <vocabulary>to be mixed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as with 交ぜる. So long as you know the ま portion of that word's reading, you'll be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: My dog runs around when she sees the snow.
examples.ja: うちの犬は、雪を見ると走り回る。

examples.en: During the summer vacation, there are many small children and adults running around on the beach.
examples.ja: 夏休みは小さい子も大人も、ビーチで走り回る人が多いです。

examples.en: The president is running around in the company today as usual.
examples.ja: 社長は今日も会社の中で走り回っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the words 走る (to run) and 回る (to revolve). So, when you're running and revolving while you're doing it, you're running in circles. So, the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to run around</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are those like the words 走る and 回る. Make sure you know those words from before and apply that knowledge to read this word as well.

examples.en: My father is good at guessing if tea is cheap or expensive.
examples.ja: 父は安いお茶と高いお茶を当てるのが上手です。

examples.en: Mr. Ohtani is a genius at hitting the ball with the bat.
examples.ja: 大谷氏は、バットにボールを当てる天才です。

examples.en: I have the power to guess a person's future by their phone number.
examples.ja: 私には電話番号で、その人の未来のことを当てる力があります。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji 当 means <kanji>right</kanji> or <kanji>success</kanji>. So since this is a verb, you're doing right and success (which doesn't make much sense). Instead, you're guessing something and getting it right. So, this word means <vocabulary>to guess</vocabulary> something. Hopefully you don't have to guess too hard when it comes to the meaning of this word as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading can be remembered via the word 当たる which you learned a few levels ago. Use that knowledge to remember that this word is read as あてる. The important part is the あ.

examples.en: Both women and men can be transformed with makeup.
examples.ja: 女も男もメイクで化けることが出来る。

examples.en: Raccoon dogs are good at transforming into human beings.
examples.ja: タヌキは人間に化けるのが上手です。

examples.en: Is it true that a used Porsche turned into ten million yen after three years?
examples.ja: 中古のポルシェが三年後に一千万円に化けたって本当ですか？

examples.en: My house was transformed into a national treasure-level house with a year of renovation.
examples.ja: 私の家は一年間のリノベーションで国宝レベルの家に化けた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>change</kanji> so you'd think the verb version is "to change," but it's a bit more specific. This word means <vocabulary>to change form</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to transform</vocabulary>.

化ける means to change into something else, usually in a surprising and magical way. It's often used in stories where animals or spirits take on human forms. It can also describe transformations in real life that are so dramatic they feel unreal.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You try to transform. You want to turn into something awesome, like a dinosaur, but then *poof* you turn into a sheep. "<reading>Ba</reading>aaa," you say. "Baaa."

examples.en: After the sound of the knock, there was a sound of the doorknob being turned.
examples.ja: ノックの音の後、ドアノブを回す音がした。

examples.en: My brother is a genius at spinning pizza dough.
examples.ja: ぼくの兄はピザの生地を回す天才です。

examples.en: Please pass around more salmon sushi.
examples.ja: もっとサーモンのおすしを回して下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: You've probably seen the word 回る, which means "to revolve." This word is similar, except for you're doing the turning/rotating action on something else. You can simply say <vocabulary>to turn something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rotate something</vocabulary> when answering this question, but be sure to think of yourself actually turning/rotating something. Remember this by using the す on the end. You've taken your friend <reading>Sue</reading> and put her on a stick. You're rotating her over a fire on a spit because you're a sick cannibal.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 回る (まわ). So long as you know that level 5 word, you'll be able to read this one as well. Use both of these words together to remember their readings.

examples.en: Personally I drink both coffee and tea.
examples.ja: 私自身はコーヒーもお茶も両方のみます。

examples.en: I have never cut fish myself.
examples.ja: 私自身で魚を切ったことはありません。

examples.en: I personally have a strong desire to learn archeology, but others don't understand me.
examples.ja: 私自身は考古学を学びたいという思いが強いですが、他の人にはあまり分かってもらえません。

meaning_mnemonic: "When it comes to <kanji>somebody</kanji> like my<kanji>self</kanji>... aka <kanji>I</kanji>..." When you say this you're really saying "<vocabulary>personally</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>as for me</vocabulary>."
reading_mnemonic: The readings are a bit weird here. The 私 is わたし and the rest is on'yomi kanji readings. So, it's a mix of both, I'm afraid. "When it comes to me, I like mixing up on'yomi and kun'yomi because I hate myself."

examples.en: I want to enter a private university.
examples.ja: 私立大学に入学したいです。

examples.en: I thought I'd be able to make a good living if I graduated from a well-known private university.
examples.ja: 有名私立大学を出れば、きっと上手く生きていけると思ったんです。

examples.en: Private universities have many foreign students as well.
examples.ja: 私立大学の学生は外国人も多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 私立, which is "private," and you've seen 大学, which is "college" or "university." So, combine them together and you have a <vocabulary>private college</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>private university</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know the readings of the words 私立 and 大学 you'll be able to read this. It's also all jukugo on'yomi readings too, so you can read it that way.

examples.en: I learned the conjugated form in the previous class.
examples.ja: その活用形は、前回のクラスで学びました。

examples.en: The last presentation didn't go well, but I think it will be okay this time.
examples.ja: 前回のプレゼンはダメでしたが、今回は平気だと思います。

examples.en: At the last event, I didn't get the writer's autograph.
examples.ja: 前回のイベントでは、作家のサインはもらえなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>before</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> was <vocabulary>last time</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>previous time</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Because of my layoff, physically and mentally I'm torn apart.
examples.ja: 会社を首にされ、身も心もズタズタです。

examples.en: Blowfish are a white-fleshed fish.
examples.ja: フグは白身の魚です。

examples.en: At that time, my mother had a gold bracelet on.
examples.ja: その時、母は金のブレスレットを身につけてました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>somebody</kanji>, but the word is <vocabulary>body</vocabulary>. I guess somebody is somebody's body, so they are similar at least. It also refers to <vocabulary>animal flesh</vocabulary> sometimes, meaning the non-bone edible parts of animals, including seafood. It's the "mi" in sashimi!

Wonder about the difference between 体 and 身? 体 refers to physical human and animal bodies, often describing their condition, appearance, etc. While 身 can also mean "physical human body," it can also refer to the self as an individual and be used to indicate one’s social standing or position. That's why you might see 身 used in idiomatic phrases like 身につく, which refers to acquiring or mastering something, like a skill.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Who is that somebody? Who is that <vocabulary>body</vocabulary>? Why, of course it is <reading>me</reading> (み).

examples.en: This is a floor above ground.
examples.ja: ここは、地上のフロアです。

examples.en: The rocket is now 3,000 meters above the ground.
examples.ja: ロケットは今、地上三千メートルにいる。

examples.en: You can see the size of the Tokyo Tower if you look up from the ground.
examples.ja: 東京タワーは、地上から見上げると、大きさがよく分かりますね。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 地下, which is "below ground." Well, this is <kanji>ground</kanji> and <kanji>above</kanji> combined together, so I bet you can guess that this means <vocabulary>above ground</vocabulary>. But usually things above ground don't float (unless you're in space), so it's really <vocabulary>on the ground</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can you turn it towards the back a little more?
examples.ja: もう少し後ろに向けることは出来ますか？

examples.en: Please look at your child, not your smartphone.
examples.ja: スマホじゃなくて子どもに、目を向けてあげて下さい。

examples.en: I am learning the conjugation forms for the JLPT next summer.
examples.ja: 来年の夏のJLPTに向けて活用形を学んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 向く means "to face" or "to turn towards", and this verb is related. This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. It's when someone turns or points something. That something doesn't just turn on its own. So this verb means <vocabulary>to turn something towards</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to point something at</vocabulary>.

In order to remember that this word means "to turn something towards," focus on the け. You have a bottle of ketchup in your hands and you're turning it toward your worst enemy to spray them. Picture yourself pointing the ketchup toward them.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is the same as 向く which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

examples.en: What the hell are you doing here?
examples.ja: お前は一体ここで何してるんだ？

examples.en: It's rude to call others "omae."
examples.ja: 他人のことを「お前」と言うのは失礼ですよ。

examples.en: I want to spend my life with you!
examples.ja: これからもずっとお前と生きていきたいんだよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The お is added to elevate someone in <kanji>front</kanji> of you. What do you call someone in front of you? That's right, <vocabulary>you</vocabulary>. Over time, this word has lost its sense of politeness, and nowadays it sounds very rough and often rude. This "you" is a good way to show anger, and some people also use it in very casual situations to show affection.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 前 is the kun'yomi, like the reading for the vocabulary word 前. So long as you know that word, you'll be able to read this one too.

examples.en: A beautiful beach stretches out along the Mediterranean Sea.
examples.ja: 地中海にはキレイなビーチが広がっています。

examples.en: Carpaccio with fish from the Mediterranean is this restaurant's recommendation.
examples.ja: 地中海の魚のカルパッチョが、このレストランのオススメです。

examples.en: During summer vacation, I went on a cruise in the Mediterranean Sea.
examples.ja: 夏休みは地中海でクルーズをしました。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Earth</kanji>'s <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>sea</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Mediterranean Sea</vocabulary>. You know, because it's surrounded by land. It's a sea in the middle of all that earth.

Actually, the Japanese name 地中海 matches the Latin roots of the English name too: medius for "middle" and terra for "earth." Whoa, did we just teach you some Latin? I sense a new business venture here. Wanius Kanius, anyone?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Every morning, I buy coffee at the convenience store.
examples.ja: 毎朝、私はコンビニでコーヒーを買います。

examples.en: Going to school early is my routine every morning.
examples.ja: 早く学校に行くのが、毎朝のルーティーンです。

examples.en: Every morning, my father cuts the bacon and makes breakfast.
examples.ja: 毎朝、父はベーコンを切って朝食を作ります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>morning</kanji> is <vocabulary>every morning</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: This is normal stuff, why can’t you get that?
examples.ja: こんな当たり前のこと、どうして分からないの？

examples.en: It's obvious, but it's important to take a shower every day.
examples.ja: 当たり前のことだけど、毎日シャワーをあびることは大切です。

examples.en: Say thank you every time someone does something for you, without taking it for granted.
examples.ja: 他人にしてもらったことを当たり前のことだと思わずに毎回「ありがとう」と言いましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen how 当たり means success. If you've experienced success <kanji>before</kanji>, everything after that seems to be pretty <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I want to get the water running as soon as possible.
examples.ja: 一日も早く水道から水が出るようにしたいんです。

examples.en: Is it okay for people to drink the tap water in this area?
examples.ja: この辺の水道の水は、人が口にして平気ですか？

examples.en: The water in the pool is about half tap water and half rainwater.
examples.ja: プールの中の水は、水道の水と雨水が大体半分半分です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> carries your <vocabulary>water supply</vocabulary>. In the old days, these were called <vocabulary>aqueduct</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I put the car headlights on at night.
examples.ja: 夜は車のヘッドライトを点ける。

examples.en: Please turn on the TV immediately.
examples.ja: 今すぐテレビを点けてください。

examples.en: I turned on the radio to check the news.
examples.ja: ニュースをチェックするために、ラジオを点けました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>point</kanji> so the verb version is something you need to point your finger to do. Picture pointing your finger and pushing a lightswitch <vocabulary>to turn something on</vocabulary>, in this case the light. You won't be able <vocabulary>to switch something on</vocabulary> if you can't point your finger.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You aren't able <vocabulary>to turn</vocabulary> the light on with just one finger though, you need to use <reading>two</reading> (つ). Either you have really weak fingers, or that's a really strong lightswitch. Either way, you need two fingers to switch on the light.

examples.en: Making dinner every day is Dad's duty.
examples.ja: 毎日、ディナーを作るのは、お父さんの役目です。

examples.en: My role as a dog ​​model is more important than my role as a pet dog.
examples.ja: 私のドッグモデルという役目は、ペットの犬という役目よりも、大切なんです。

examples.en: My brother’s duty now is to make money for the family in place of my father.
examples.ja: 今の兄の役目は父の代わりに家に金を入れることです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have an <kanji>eye</kanji> for <kanji>service</kanji>, then you'll always think helping people is your <vocabulary>duty</vocabulary>! If you see someone in need of service, you’ll always offer your help, because that’s your duty.
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 役 and the kun'yomi reading for 目. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

examples.en: This shirt is made of cotton fabric.
examples.ja: このシャツはコットン生地で出来ています。

examples.en: Spread the dough, then cut it and make a shape.
examples.ja: 生地を広げてから、切って、形を作ります。

examples.en: The pie dough is from a supermarket, but the rest is handmade.
examples.ja: パイ生地はスーパーのものですが、他は手作りです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Life</kanji> that comes out of the <kanji>earth</kanji> is made up of different kinds of <vocabulary>material</vocabulary>s. Sometimes it's <vocabulary>cloth</vocabulary>, sometimes it's <vocabulary>dough</vocabulary>, but everything has to be made out of something.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses a new kun'yomi reading for 生 and a new on'yomi reading for 地. You haven't learned either of these readings yet, sorry! Here's some mnemonics to help you:

If you want the best <vocabulary>material</vocabulary> to make clothes or pies out of, the <reading>key</reading> (き) is asking <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ)! He knows everything, including where to find the materials for whatever weird thing you're making. Just remember: Who's the key? Jesus!

examples.en: I always watch the same program at night.
examples.ja: 夜は、いつも同じ番組を見ます。

examples.en: That popular program got suspended due to the host's scandal.
examples.ja: あの人気番組は、ホストがスキャンダルのせいで、休止になってしまいました。

examples.en: On today's program, they were doing a documentary about a big family of fifteen people.
examples.ja: 今日の番組では、十五人の大ファミリーのドキュメンタリーをやっていました。

meaning_mnemonic: Use a <kanji>number in a series</kanji> to <kanji>group</kanji> the things you watch and listen to. That makes them your <vocabulary>program</vocabulary>s. Your TV and radio programs, specifically. If you watch TV you'll hear it a lot!
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 番 and the kun'yomi reading for 組. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

examples.en: In junior high school, you will study nine subjects.
examples.ja: 中学では九科目学びます。

examples.en: I got an eighty on the tests for all subjects.
examples.ja: どの科目のテストも全て八十点でした。

examples.en: Mom is a teacher of subjects like science and mathematics.
examples.ja: お母さんは科学や数学などの科目の先生です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you've got an <kanji>eye</kanji> on a certain <kanji>course</kanji>, it's a <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> you really want to take. Maybe you're in school and that means you'll be taking a lot of <vocabulary>course</vocabulary>s. Maybe you're a teacher and you're planning out your <vocabulary>curriculum</vocabulary>. Either way, you have your eye on the course-prize.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, but you learned the kun'yomi reading for 目 before. So, you have to remember that this word uses もく instead of め. To do that, imagine seeing that the <vocabulary>subjects</vocabulary> you're allowed to take next term are different than everyone else's. The other kids notice, and start <reading>mock</reading>ing (もく) you for it. Think of what those subjects are and how you're being mocked for having to take them.

examples.en: It's been a few years since I came to Japan.
examples.ja: 日本に来てから、数年です。

examples.en: I met a former partner for the first time in a few years.
examples.ja: 数年ぶりに、元パートナーに会いました。

examples.en: Oh, did you just remember? We met once at a cosplay event a few years ago.
examples.ja: あ、思い出しました？数年前に一回、コスプレのイベントでお会いしたことがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: When a <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>year</kanji>s have passed you say that <vocabulary>several years</vocabulary> have passed! You don't want to say how many years, so just say several years.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Type a message mixed up with some emoji.
examples.ja: 絵文字を交ぜて、メッセージを入力しましょう。

examples.en: Take a closer look at this receipt emoji. Can you see the letters?
examples.ja: このレシートの絵文字、よく見て下さい。🧾文字が見えませんか？

examples.en: Young people in college are good at communicating using emoji.
examples.ja: その大学生の青年は絵文字を使ってコミュニケーションをすることが上手です。

meaning_mnemonic: When you use a <kanji>picture</kanji> to replace your <kanji>letter</kanji>s to type, you're using <vocabulary>emoji</vocabulary>! Those are the faces you send when you text or email.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My father is a professional pitcher.
examples.ja: 父は、プロの投手です。

examples.en: Ohtani is a master pitcher and hitter.
examples.ja: 大谷氏は投手の名人でありバッターの名人でもあります。

examples.en: The pitcher on the Mexican team is very strong.
examples.ja: メキシコのチームの投手はとても強いです。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 手 means "hand," but it can also mean "doer," as in someone who performs a particular action or task. Why? Because we use our hands to do things. And when it comes to <kanji>throw</kanji>ing, the <kanji>doer</kanji> is the <vocabulary>pitcher</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 手 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

To be a good <vocabulary>pitcher</vocabulary>, all you have to do is put the ball into the <reading>chute</reading> (しゅ). Pitchers don't actually throw the ball. There is an invisible pitching chute right on the mound. You slide the ball into the chute and off it goes!

examples.en: But I can't.
examples.ja: でも、できないよ。

examples.en: But are you okay with that?
examples.ja: でも、いいの？

examples.en: But it's 50 percent off, you know?
examples.ja: でも、５０パーセントオフだよ？

meaning_mnemonic:
I want to show you my <reading>demo</reading> (でも), <vocabulary>but</vocabulary> you don't want to see it. <vocabulary>However</vocabulary>, I'm going to show it to you anyway. So there.

Something to watch out for with でも is that it always goes at the beginning of a sentence, not in the middle, like "but" usually does in English. It’s also a fairly casual word, so it’s not normally used in formal situations.

examples.en: I don't know that yet.
examples.ja: それはまだ分からないよ。

examples.en: What, are you still in the bathroom?
examples.ja: え、まだトイレにいるの？

examples.en: If you're looking for Ken, he's still taking a shower.
examples.ja: ケンなら、まだシャワーしてるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've been getting <reading>madder</reading> (まだ) and madder, and you’re <vocabulary>still</vocabulary> mad. You’re <vocabulary>not yet</vocabulary> as mad as you could be, though.

You can use まだ to talk about a situation that started in the past and continues into the present. Wait! Where are you going? I'm still explaining this! I'm not done yet!

examples.en: Let's eat here!
examples.ja: ここで食べよう！

examples.en: If you're looking for your glasses, they're here.
examples.ja: メガネなら、ここにあるよ。

examples.en: Where am I? Who am I?
examples.ja: ここはどこ？私はだれ？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how words beginning with こ are close to you? It ends with こ too, which is a clue that we’re talking about a place. So ここ means <vocabulary>here</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Today I ate a muffin as a snack.
examples.ja: 今日はおやつにマフィンを食べた。

examples.en: Shall we take a snack break?
examples.ja: そろそろおやつにする？

examples.en: Kaori's snacks are always homemade!
examples.ja: カオリちゃんのおやつは、いつも手作りだよ！

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Oh yah! Two</reading> (おやつ) <vocabulary>snack</vocabulary>s, just for you. Imagine your two snacks. What are they? I bet they're delicious. Oh yah!

おやつ can be anything from candy to cookies to onigiri. Basically, it's anything fairly light that’s eaten between meals.

examples.en: Where are you going?
examples.ja: どこに行くの？

examples.en: Which McDonald's?
examples.ja: どこのマクドナルド？

examples.en: Where do you come from?
examples.ja: どこから来たの？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how words beginning with ど are often question words, and words ending in こ refer to places? This one's no exception, so どこ means <vocabulary>where</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Hello, this is Yamakawa.
examples.ja: もしもし、山川です。

examples.en: Hello, can you hear me?
examples.ja: もしもし、きこえますか？

examples.en: Hello, what are you doing now?
examples.ja: もしもし、今なにしてるの？

meaning_mnemonic:
Woah, this place is <reading>mossy</reading>, <reading>mossy</reading> (もしもし)! This moss needs clearing up, so you call up the person in charge. <vocabulary>Hello</vocabulary>, says the person on the phone.

もしもし is a <vocabulary>telephone hello</vocabulary>, the standard way to answer the phone in Japan!

examples.en: The two rivals are finally set to face off.
examples.ja: 二人のライバルがついに対決することになった。

examples.en: Someday, I'd like to go head-to-head with that chef.
examples.ja: いつかあのシェフと1対1で対決してみたいな。

examples.en: Alright, now I have all the items I need for the showdown with the boss!
examples.ja: よし、これでボスキャラとの対決にいるアイテムがそろったぞ！

meaning_mnemonic:
When it's you <kanji>versus</kanji> someone else to <kanji>decide</kanji> it all, you know this is a <vocabulary>showdown</vocabulary>. It's a decisive <vocabulary>confrontation</vocabulary>!

対決 is when two sides go head-to-head in a serious match or showdown. Think rivals <vocabulary>facing off</vocabulary> in a big game or the final battle in an anime. It's tense and dramatic, but also exciting — like, "Alright, this is it. Time to settle things. Who's gonna come out on top?"
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Rugby is very popular in South Africa.
examples.ja: 南アフリカではラグビーがとても人気です。

examples.en: If I go to South Africa, I want to see lions.
examples.ja: 南アフリカに行ったら、ライオンが見たいです。

examples.en: Elon Musk was born in Pretoria, South Africa.
examples.ja: イーロン・マスクは南アフリカのプレトリアで生まれました。

examples.en: When I was backpacking, I traveled around the countries of Southern Africa by hitchhiking.
examples.ja: バックパッカーをしていた時、ヒッチハイクで南アフリカの国々をまわりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This combines <kanji>south</kanji> and アフリカ, the word for "Africa." Put them together to get <vocabulary>South Africa</vocabulary>. 

南アフリカ will almost always mean the country of South Africa, but in some contexts it'll occasionally refer to the wider region of <vocabulary>Southern Africa</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading uses the kun'yomi for 南, which you've already learned. Yay for geography! Now which continent was South Africa on again…?

examples.en: A cold north wind is blowing.
examples.ja: つめたい北風がふいています。

examples.en: It was a cold day with a northerly wind blowing.
examples.ja: その日は、北風がふくさむい日でした。

examples.en: The puppies were running around in the north wind with great energy.
examples.ja: 北風の中を、子犬たちは元気に走りまわっていました。

examples.en: I have a date coming up, but the north wind is so strong that my wig looks like a lion.
examples.ja: これからデートなのに、北風が強すぎて、ウィッグがライオンみたいになってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
From the <kanji>north</kanji> comes a <kanji>wind</kanji>. Naturally, it's the <vocabulary>north wind</vocabulary>.

北風 blows down from the north, and in Japan is often associated with the colder temperatures it brings.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. Almost like it's two independent vocab words, 北 and 風, mashed together. You've learned these readings, but the かぜ reading is still pretty new, so here's a mnemonic just in case:

Imagine the <vocabulary>north wind</vocabulary> blowing a kami<reading>kaze</reading> (かぜ) off course. The kamikaze pilot tries to complete his mission, but he can't overcome the wind blowing down from the north. Hear the kamikaze crying out, "Curse you, north wind!" In a way though, it kind of saves his life.

examples.en: The sky at dawn today was pink.
examples.ja: 今日の夜明けの空はピンクでした。

examples.en: Things are tough right now, but a new dawn will come.
examples.ja: 今はつらいけど、いつか夜明けが来るよ。

examples.en: My parents are the generation that experienced the dawn of the internet age.
examples.ja: 私の両親は、インターネット時代の夜明けを経験した世代です。

meaning_mnemonic:
We have <kanji>night</kanji> and the noun version of "to dawn" (明ける). What comes when the night ends and a new day dawns? The <vocabulary>dawn</vocabulary>, of course.

夜明け refers to dawn or <vocabulary>daybreak</vocabulary> in the literal sense, but it can also be used metaphorically to mean the <vocabulary>beginning</vocabulary> of something new, as in 時代の夜明け (the dawn of an era).
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You know 明け because it uses the same reading as 明ける, but 夜 is a little weird because よる gets shortened to よ. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this change:

What are you doing when <vocabulary>dawn</vocabulary> comes each morning? Playing with your <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ), obviously. You want to be the best yo-yoer there's ever been, so you're up with the dawn every morning, practicing your yo-yo skills while the competition sleeps.

Note that in the related phrase 夜が明ける, 夜 is also often read as よ.
